rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's lesson is about helping our children follow instructions and rules by using consequences

Consequences are the results of actions and behaviours. Parents can use a planned consequence when children don’t follow a rule or instruction. 

For example if a child doesn’t follow the rule to put away their toys before dinner, then a consequence could be that the child can’t watch YouTube after dinner. 

Giving clear consequences teaches children that their actions affect themselves and others.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's lesson is about helping our children follow instructions and rules by using consequences

Consequences are the results of actions and behaviours. Parents can use a planned consequence when children don’t follow a rule or instruction. 

For example if a child doesn’t follow the rule to put away their toys before dinner, then a consequence could be that the child can’t watch YouTube after dinner. 

Giving clear consequences teaches children that their actions affect themselves and others.

media_title.eng: How will it help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
We all misbehave sometimes! 

As parents, we are also sometimes tempted to scream and shout when our children misbehave. But that just makes everything worse for everyone.

If we stay calm and give our children a consequence instead, they start to learn to take responsibility for their actions and we avoid the anger that comes with hitting or shouting.

rows.media_title: How will it help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
We all misbehave sometimes! 

As parents, we are also sometimes tempted to scream and shout when our children misbehave. But that just makes everything worse for everyone.

If we stay calm and give our children a consequence instead, they start to learn to take responsibility for their actions and we avoid the anger that comes with hitting or shouting.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s see how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name uses consequences to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name follow instructions:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s see how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name uses consequences to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name follow instructions:

character_1_text.eng: You are playing so nice and quiet, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to clean up your toys.

rows.character_1_text: You are playing so nice and quiet, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to clean up your toys.

character_1_text.eng: It’s time to put away your toys

rows.character_1_text: It’s time to put away your toys
@data.characters.f3_son_4.name, either you put away the toys now, or you won’t be able to play with your toys after dinner.

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, either you put away the toys now, or you won’t be able to play with your toys after dinner.

character_2_text.eng: No Uncle! I don’t want to! I’m not finished with my game.

rows.character_2_text: No Uncle! I don’t want to! I’m not finished with my game.

rows.character_1_text: Because you did not clean up your toys when I asked you to, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, you cannot play with your toys after dinner. Now please come and wash your hands.

character_1_text.eng: Because you did not clean up your toys when I asked you to, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, you cannot play with your toys after dinner. Now please come and wash your hands.

rows.character_1_text: Good job washing your hands so well, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name.

character_1_text.eng: Good job washing your hands so well, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s reflect on how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name used a consequence here.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name used a consequence here.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Because @data.characters.f3_son_4.name does not put his toys away even when he has a choice between listening and a consequence.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Yes! Using a consequence in this situation is a good way to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn to make decisions.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Because he already tried yelling, and it didn’t work.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: He speaks in a calm, firm way, explains why he is giving a consequence, and connects the consequence to the behaviour.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: That’s right. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it’s important to introduce consequences when you are feeling calm and makes sure that @data.characters.f3_son_4.name understands why he can’t play after dinner. There’s one more right answer hiding! Did you find it?

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: He gets a bit angry, but then makes the consequence clear.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: That’s right. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it’s important to follow-through for the consequence to work. There’s one more right answer hiding! Did you find it?

quiz_3_question.eng:
What would @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn if @data.characters.f3_uncle.name gives in or does not give the consequence? 

@data.characters.f3_son_4.name would learn:

quiz_3_option_1_text.eng: He can get away with this behaviour in the future and not to take @data.characters.f3_uncle.name seriously when he gives an instruction

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.

quiz_3_option_2_text.eng: That @data.characters.f3_uncle.name loves him and forgives him.

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Children actually do need consequences and the boundaries that they come with in order to feel secure and loved.

@data.characters.f3_son_4.name would learn:
rows.quiz_3_option_1_text: He can get away with this behaviour in the future and not to take @data.characters.f3_uncle.name seriously when he gives an instruction

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child misbehaves:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child misbehaves:

section_1_text.eng: Involve your children in planning consequences when you create household rules.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Discuss possible consequences together and explain the reasons.

Older children can suggest ideas, making them more likely to understand and follow the rules.

Introduce consequences to your child when the child is calm.

section_2_text.eng: Choose consequences that are connected to the behaviour. Example: If toys aren’t put away, they can’t be used the next day.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
Make sure the consequence is reasonable for your child’s age and not too severe.

If a natural consequence already exists (like a toy breaking), you may not need to add another one, but should draw your child’s attention to the natural consequence.

section_3_text.eng: Take deep breaths or walk away if you need to calm down first.

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Respond in a calm, clear way. Keep your voice at a quiet level, keep your message short, and use words that your child will understand.

Shouting only makes things worse and teaches the wrong lesson. Don’t give consequences when a child is already dysregulated, or you are angry. 

Delay until you can talk calmly.

rows.section_1_text: Involve your children in planning consequences when you create household rules.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Discuss possible consequences together and explain the reasons.

Older children can suggest ideas, making them more likely to understand and follow the rules.

Introduce consequences to your child when the child is calm.
rows.section_2_text: Choose consequences that are connected to the behaviour. Example: If toys aren’t put away, they can’t be used the next day.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
Make sure the consequence is reasonable for your child’s age and not too severe.

If a natural consequence already exists (like a toy breaking), you may not need to add another one, but should draw your child’s attention to the natural consequence.
rows.section_3_text: Take deep breaths or walk away if you need to calm down first.
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Respond in a calm, clear way. Keep your voice at a quiet level, keep your message short, and use words that your child will understand.

Shouting only makes things worse and teaches the wrong lesson. Don’t give consequences when a child is already dysregulated, or you are angry. 

Delay until you can talk calmly.

section_1_text.eng: Be consistent with the rules you set—children learn what to expect. Consequences need to feel predictable to the child.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Consequences need to feel fair. Don’t change a consequence that you’ve agreed on because you feel angry in the moment.

Always follow through once you give a consequence. Older children may engage in discussion, problem-solving or reflection, but make sure you come back to the consequence.

section_2_text.eng:
Try to avoid consequences by giving clear instructions and redirecting first.

Before giving a consequence, give your child a choice and 5–10 seconds to start following the instruction.

Follow all of the building blocks for giving clear and specific instructions.

Repeat your instruction ONCE with a choice to comply or receive a consequence: “If you do not do it now, you cannot play with your toys after dinner.”

section_2_extra_text.eng:
Say the same words and speak calmly, slowly, and firmly. Make sure your child is paying attention. 

If your child decides to comply after having been given a choice, praise your child for following the instruction – even if your child is unhappy about it. 

Remember to manage tantrums and whining by ignoring your child’s behaviour (but not the child!).

section_3_text.eng:
Consequences should be immediate, reasonable, and realistic.

If you have to give the consequence, move on to a new activity instead of insisting that the child still follows the instruction.

If your child forgets or breaks a household rule related to safety, give the consequence immediately.

section_3_extra_text.eng:
It is okay to show your disappointment when your child forgets a Household Rule. Make it clear that your disappointment is about your child’s action and not your child. For example, you can say, “I love you even when you do something disappointing.”

Consequences are not punishments. They teach children responsibility for actions and self-discipline.

Consequences should be immediate, reasonable, and realistic.

If your child forgets or breaks a household rule related to safety, give the consequence immediately.

It is okay to show your disappointment when your child forgets a Household Rule. Make it clear that your disappointment is about your child’s action and not your child. For example, you can say, “I love you even when you do something disappointing.”

Consequences are not punishments. They teach children responsibility for actions and self-discipline.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.

quiz_1_question.eng: Would any of these consequences be helpful for you and your child?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: If you are late for dinner, your food will be cold.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: If you continue splashing water out of the bathtub, bath time will be over.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: If you break your toy, you will have no toy to play with.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: If you can’t play in the garden where I can see you, then you will have to come inside.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_5_text.eng: If you do not put away your toys before you go to bed, then you cannot play with them tomorrow morning.

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out tomorrow.

quiz_1_option_6_text.eng: None of these will work in my home.

quiz_1_feedback_6.eng: That's okay! Try to think of just one consequence that you feel confident you can follow-through with in a calm way. Try starting with something small.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Remember that praising your child for the things you would like them to keep doing is a good way to see more positive behaviour in your home. 

Your home activity is to have a discussion with your child about one persistent challenging household rule and discuss a possible consequence. 

Using fair and realistic consequences is also part of building a positive relationship with your child.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Remember that praising your child for the things you would like them to keep doing is a good way to see more positive behaviour in your home. 

Your home activity is to have a discussion with your child about one persistent challenging household rule and discuss a possible consequence. 

Using fair and realistic consequences is also part of building a positive relationship with your child.

quiz_1_question.eng: The next time your child cannot follow instructions, can you calmly use a fair consequence?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Keep trying. It will get easier in time. You can start by considering smaller behaviours that your child struggles with and planning a fair consequence in advance so you're ready. Remember to take a pause to calm down before you respond.

rows.quiz_1_question: The next time your child cannot follow instructions, can you calmly use a fair consequence?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. Keep trying. It will get easier in time. You can start by considering smaller behaviours that your child struggles with and planning a fair consequence in advance so you're ready. Remember to take a pause to calm down before you respond.
